conclusion: Understanding the graph shows the reciprocal of velocity as a function of displacement.
The graph is a straight line starting from the origin, passing through points A, B, A', B', C, C'.
1/v is directly proportional to x, suggesting as displacement increases, the reciprocal of velocity increases linearly.
Velocity is the derivative of displacement with respect to time, v = dx/dt.
If 1/v is increasing with x, then dt/dx is increasing, implying velocity is decreasing.
If velocity is decreasing as displacement increases, the particle is decelerating.

v = 1/(kx), and since v = dx/dt, dx/dt = 1/(kx).

Acceleration is negative and varies inversely with the cube of the displacement, indicating deceleration.
